Does he agree that this course of action, if pursued, constitutes a most flagrant breach of a specific promise made in writing to the Australian electorate during the election campaign and could, according to industry estimates, cost up to 8,000 jobs as the market would clearly prefer to buy imported tyres which would be cheaper than retreads if sales tax were applied? Is he prepared to give an undertaking that the Government will reconsider this decision?

—I will seek an answer from Mr Willis to the first part of Senator Chipp's question. In regard to the second part of his question, it is correct that the Minister for Finance stated that no action would be taken to overturn the determination previously made by the Commissioner of Taxation on this matter . There are a number of reasons for that decision. Firstly, and most importantly , the full enormity of the Budget deficit which this Government had inherited required the Government to look more closely at the revenue implications of the Taxation Commissioner's decision. Secondly, it is not correct, as Senator Chipp has said, that people will be buying new, imported tyres instead of having old tyres retreaded. It is not correct for two reasons: Firstly, because a person who supplies his or her own casing for a retread will not be liable to pay tax on the casing but will be liable to pay tax only on the retreaded component-the value added to the casing-and, secondly, because, according to the advice that I have received--
—Isn't that a tax on labour?

—It is a tax on the value added to it in precisely the same way that virtually all manufacturing output is subject to varying rates of sales tax . The second reason that they are not likely to do what Senator Chipp suggested is, I am advised, that the price of a new tyre of comparable size is $45.50; the price of a retread, even if the sales tax were applied to both the retread and the casing, would be about $28.60. Senator Chipp asked also about employment implications. Quite clearly the claims that it will cost 8,000 jobs are gross exaggerations. It is not at all clear whether there will be any net employment effects whatsoever.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the Government reviewed the decision of the previous Government, as recommended to it by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, to contract out to the private sector the manufacture of artificial limbs for the repatriation free limb scheme? If so, what is the Government's intention?

—Senator Childs asks me about a decision I made recently to overturn the decision made by the previous Government as a result of a recommendation of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions which sought to hand over to private enterprise a considerable proportion of the work undertaken by the Government; that is, work undertaken at repatriation and artificial limbs and appliance centres. I saw fit to change that decision because it was proven to be very costly to the Commonwealth. The figures show that, despite the fact that there was an increase of only 4.7 per cent from one year to the next in the manufacture of artificial limbs and that repairs decreased by 13.7 per cent, the total cost went up by a dramatic 28.8 per cent. So we finished up with no cost benefit as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions but an increase in government expenditure which denied the very purpose of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. I have taken the additional step of indicating that no new manufacturers will participate in the free limb scheme and that the Government's operation will continue, with a great deal of assistance from the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Since he now pleads the streaker's defence in relation to the spy flights fiasco, will he also accept the public condemnation which inevitably follows from such acts of irrational exhibitionism?
—I have been on the receiving end of a series of po-faced editorials on this subject. Now I am in receipt of a po-faced question from the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory-
—Thank you for reminding us all. This is terrific.

—The senator for the Australian Capital Territory. It is a matter of some difficulty coming to grips with these new power relationships, Mr President, but we are working on it. I, of course, accept that some forms of criticism of the action that took place are valid. I have readily acknowledged that. I believe that other forms of criticism have been wildly astray and have totally missed the point.

—Does the Minister for Resources and Energy acknowledge the imperative need of a new legislative framework to govern the limited development of Australia's uranium resources to replace the utterly inappropriate legislative framework devised in the 1950s when Australia's uranium was used in the nuclear weapons programs of our allies? When does the Minister intend to bring to the Parliament legislation to govern the transition phase of the operations of existing mines in accordance with the policy of the Australian Labor Party? In the meantime, will he give an assurance to this chamber that those powers of a kind which are offensive to civil liberties and conferred by much of the present legislation will not be exercised by Ministers or officials of this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is planned by the Government that legislation of the type outlined by Senator Tate will be introduced. The exact time at which it will be introduced has not yet been determined. In addition to the matters to which Senator Tate referred, we envisage significant amendments to the operations of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission so that its three current and, to some extent, conflicting functions-its research, regulatory and commercial functions- will be split into three different organisations, as was envisaged in the Labor Party's platform. Some changes were made to the Atomic Energy Commission in 1981 . I understand that the previous Government also had legislation in the pipeline with respect at least to the Atomic Energy Commission, if not to the other matters to which Senator Tate referred.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said earlier, the time at which this legislation will be introduced has not yet been determined. I propose to submit the matter to the Government party' s relevant committee for input and discussion. I also invite input and suggestions from members of the Opposition as to the precise way in which this legislation should be amended in order to achieve in the most expeditious way the objectives set out in the Labor Party's official platform.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Minister agree that the Republic of Indonesia has never had, and does not have, any historic, cultural, ethnic or, indeed, moral justification for its invasion and occupation of East Timor? Is it not a fact that Australia owes a substantial debt of honour to the people of East Timor for the heroic way in which they helped our servicemen during World War II, often at the cost of their own lives? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will maintain its declared policy of self-determination for East Timor? Alternatively, does the Government porpose to sacrifice East Timor to a policy of appeasement, for fear of what the Foreign Minister is reported to have described in this morning's Press as Indonesian retaliation, such as the withdrawal of landing rights for Qantas Airways Ltd? If so, how far would this policy of appeasement go? For instance, would it be maintained if Indonesia made incursions into the territory of Papua New Guinea?

—The answer to the first and second parts of the question is yes. With regard to the remainder of the question, I draw the honourable senator 's attention to the detailed Press statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the conclusion of his visit to Jakarta. The situation is obviously fluid. Australia has obvious moral obligations to press the point about the absence of self-determination having been allowed to the Timorese people. It is a matter for judgment, which will have to work itself out in the months ahead, as to how that strong expression of a moral viewpoint, to which our party certainly remains strongly committed, can be accommodated with the overall pattern of Australia's interests here and in the region. Nothing that the Foreign Minister has said in any way reflects a derogation from the policy position which has been strongly expressed over a long period by the Australian Labor Party.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister may not be in a position-that would be reasonable-to answer the last point I made. I asked: Would this policy be maintained if Indonesia made incursions into the territory of Papua New Guinea?

—I simply make the point that the question is highly hypothetical and suppositious. No doubt if activity of that kind occurred a dramatic change in our perception of regional relationships would take place.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it the Government's intention to honour the funding commitments which his predecessor made during the recent election campaign? In particular, I am interested to hear about the grants which the previous Minister made with regard to senior citizens centres in South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, in general the Government will honour the funding commitments entered into by the previous Government. The centres which the honourable senator mentioned have created some difficulty for both the Federal Government and the South Australian State Government. The previous Government announced to the State Minister, the Honourable Greg Crafter, on 2 March, only three days before the election, the expenditure of some $500,000 under the States Grants (Home Care) Act on senior citizens centres, I think at Gawler, Elizabeth and Blackwood. Honourable senators may know that these centres are in fact funded by a combination of State and Federal Government money and in general the Federal Government follows as much as possible and within budgetary limits the recommendations of the State Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty in this situation was that there had been a change of government in South Australia in November. The present Minister involved, the Minister of Community Welfare, in fact was very surprised when he received on 2 March a Press statement announcing Federal Government funding for centres which was contrary to the advice he had been given. He thought that this was a funny way in which to consult with State governments. A similar situation happened in Western Australia where an attempt was made, according to my understanding, to get the State Labor Minister to agree with priorities which had been established by the previous Liberal Minister.

I found some difficulty when faced with a situation in which the previous Government quite clearly ignored the wishes of the existing State governments and chose to follow the views of the previous State Government, even though in South Australia that Government had been rejected by the people in the previous November. I also found it rather difficult to deal with grants which had been announced like this only two or three days before the election. Perhaps the Minister involved did not believe that anything could happen on 5 March. Unfortunately for him, it did.

However, there is no question that the people who sought funding for these senior citizens centres had their expectations raised. It was announced officially that they would receive such funding. In consultation with both State Ministers, we have agreed that it would be wrong of us in these circumstances to withdraw this funding even though the situation in Western Australia involves of necessity considerable funding in the next financial year. So the people involved in, I think, the Gawler, Elizabeth and Blackwood senior citizens centres can rest assured that they will get their funding. I am disturbed only at the manner in which those grants were announced by the previous Government and, in particular, their timing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up the Attorney-General's offer to answer questions on the spy flights, not on his non-justifying justifications of his decision but on one of his remarks since when he was reported to have said: ' There is a lot of difference between flying over at 30,000 feet and hot-dogging at 200 feet'. Does he not realise that in making those sorts of remarks he is belittling the role of the Mirage pilot who was in fact acting under orders and trying to make the best use of the equipment available to meet an urgent Government request? Does he not agree that this apparent attempt to make an Air Force officer a scapegoat for the whole disgraceful business is inappropriate for the first law officer of the Commonwealth?

—I think that my expression was a natural reflection of the frustration I felt at the way in which what appeared on the face of it to be a perfectly rational request was communicated down through the bowels of the Defence establishment in such a way that it came out at the other end in a form which was very far from rational in all the circumstances of the case.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs inform the Senate whether any communication has been received from the Queensland Premier indicating his Government's response to the recent publication in the Australian Medical Journal of statistics on Aboriginal health which indicate that mortality and morbidity rates in Queensland, particularly on Aboriginal reserves, are considerably higher than for the rest of the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, is very concerned about the reports which have been made public in the media over the last few days concerning the appalling health situation of Aboriginals living on reserves in Queensland. We are distressed but not surprised because for some years now, prior to our being in government, we sought to raise this matter continually in this place and in the other place. We sought to persuade the previous Government to take some Commonwealth or Federal action in response to this extraordinary and intolerable situation. So we are not amazed although, of course, we are deeply concerned by the news of health problems which are on an even greater scale than those documented in recent reports such as that of the World Council of Churches.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to give the honourable senator an answer with regard to any response by the Premier of Queensland because I have no information that such a response has been made. However the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has met with the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs, Mr Bird, on a range of matters, some of which I think will cover the health issues which have been raised. These discussions are in progress and are continuing. The Federal Minister has called for an urgent report from his Department on the situation of Aboriginal health in Queensland. He has also asked the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs for further information on these matters. If any more information regarding the Queensland Government's attitude to the information becomes available I will certainly let the honourable senator have it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Attorney-General regarding the military spy flights over Tasmania. Will the Attorney-General table his letter to the Minister for Defence requesting Air Force help? Has he yet responded to the requests lodged by the Australian newspaper under the Freedom of Information Act seeking other documents on his actions? If not, when does he intend responding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I and the Australian Labor Party Government remain committed to the principles of freedom of action-freedom of information; Freud is alive and well in the Senate today. I and the Government remain fully committed to the principles of freedom of information and, indeed, the practice of freedom of information. Under those circumstances I am prepared, after consultation with my colleague the Minister for Defence and one or two other people in this instance, to table in the Parliament, and indeed table right now, a series of documents covering Royal Australian Air Force aerial photographic surveys over the listed World Heritage site. The documents that I table now are in two bundles: First of all, a series of 17 documents in the possession of the Attorney-General's Department; and secondly, a bundle of 33 documents in the possession of the Department of Defence. There is some overlap in content as between the two because there has been a degree of minute swapping, as might be appreciated, in the last few days. I am advised that the documents now tabled are all those directly related to the requesting of the survey, the flights which took place, and the explanation by Ministers of the sequence of events.
—Are there any photos?

—I am not tabling the photographs themselves at this stage. However, if the honourable senators were to express an interest in seeing them I would be only too delighted to see whether arrangements could be made for some prints, or at least a fair sample of the 200 feet of continuous film, to be made available for inspection in the Parliamentary Library. Indeed, I indicate that I am prepared to make that material available to the Tasmanian Premier. Might I indicate in relation to the tabling and free and full disclosure of this information that there are two particular points in relation to which hormones might be set racing if I do not anticipate the point at this stage. The first point is this: There is an apparent discrepancy between the account by Mr Glare of my Department in his minute dated 11 April 1983 and that of Major-General Gration in his minute of the same date as to whether a telephone conversation between Mr Glare and Group Captain Waterfield took place at about 1 p.m. or 3 p. m. on 5 April 1983. This point is clarified in the note for file by Mr Glare which is dated 18 April 1983 and which is also part of that tabled bundle of documents.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point concerns the time of my conversation on 5 April with Mr Scholes when he gave his oral approval for the RAAF survey flight. There is no doubt that this conversation took place when both of us were present for the Cabinet meeting which took place on the afternoon of that day. My own clear recollection, as is indicated in my letter to Mr Scholes of 20 April, which letter is also included in this bundle of material, is that the conversation took place just before that Cabinet meeting began. I table the documents in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. In view of the importance of these documents, will the Attorney seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard rather than tabling them?

—That is a matter for the Attorney-General. He has tabled the documents. From what I see of them from the chair, I think there would be an enormous problem in having them printed in Hansard. There is no point of order.

—I am indebted to you for those remarks, Mr President, but I indicate that copies of the material in question will be available for honourable senators, I gather in the near future-possibly later today.

—I address a question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. What steps does the Government intend to take to redress the present educational disadvantage which is suffered by women and girls in our community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is acutely aware of the educational and, indeed, employment disadvantages suffered by women and girls. Those honourable senators who paid attention to the Governor-General's Speech would have heard within that Speech a number of very general and wide-ranging commitments to overcome these disadvantages. Undoubtedly, many of the disadvantages that young women are currently experiencing on the labour market stem from the disadvantages and the unequal opportunities which they have in the school system.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already set in train a number of initiatives by which these disadvantages can be overcome. As I have indicated, I want one of the priority areas for the revived national curriculum development exercise to be in this area of the education of girls. We will also be asking the Schools Commission to upgrade its efforts in this direction and to that end I will shortly be making an announcement concerning the appointment of a new commissioner. In general, all of the projects funded through the Schools Commission and all of the activities of my Department will now be pursued in such a way that they offer full and real equal opportunity to girls and boys in post-secondary education-to women as with men.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a further response from the Attorney-General following a reply to my colleague Senator Hill about the extraordinary precedent of ordering Royal Australian Air Force planes into a party political mission. If the Air Force special flight had not become known, as a champion of open government did the Attorney-General intend to offer to the Tasmanian Government before today the photographs taken by the Defence Force planes? If so, at what stage did he intend to do so?

—I indicated earlier that the point in obtaining the photographs was to acquire, in a non-provocative and non-confrontationist way, a record of the course of events during the phase of the dam construction that was proceeding notwithstanding the existence of prohibitions in Commonwealth law pending the determination of the High Court case. Had it come to a situation in which, as a result of the evidence of these photographs or any other evidence, it became necessary for the Commonwealth to seek an interim injunction or some other form of legal redress in which those photographs had evidentiary relevance , of course the material would have been put into those court proceedings. No doubt in the course of those court proceedings it would have been made available to the other side. As I indicated earlier, there was certainly no intention to deceive at any stage in this exercise. There was a manifest intention to avoid undue provocation.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. If the Minister intended not to be provocative why did he not order a Transport Australia plane? Why was it necessary, given the sophisticated photographic equipment of the Air Force, to go below 1,000 feet on at least four separate occasions?
—Order! I do not know that that was a supplementary question, but I will allow it on this occasion.

—I am advised that no civilian aircraft facility was available within the time frame we wanted-namely, in the week in which the High Court action commenced-which could have produced photographs of the quality that was necessary at any height to give an accurate depiction of what was going on in the area in question and whether, in fact, irreparable environmental damage was occurring. As to the Mirage photographs to which the honourable senator refers, the reality of the matter is that the Mirage photographs in quality bore the same relationship to the quality of the F111 photographs as the product of a Box Brownie would to that of a Leica or a Rolleiflex.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs noted that the Tasmanian Government has indicated that it has no intention of proceeding with any Aboriginal land rights legislation, despite the confidence expressed last year by Senator Baume when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that the Tasmanian Government would do what he called the right thing? Can the Minister tell the Senate what action the Commonwealth will take to ensure the implementation of the proposals on Aboriginal land rights announced in the Governor-General's Speech this afternoon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that the Tasmanian Government is of a mind not to proceed in this very vital area of achieving justice for Aboriginal people in Tasmania. However, the honourable senator will also be aware that the policy of the new Government is that land rights will be achieved in all parts of Australia and that the Federal Government will undertake the responsibility of seeing that they are achieved. Clearly, it is preferable if land rights in the States are achieved as a result of State legislation. That is obviously the most direct and most efficient way of achieving the objective of land rights.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear that several States are prepared to act in this way. South Australia, of course, already has land rights legislation and is, I understand, planning to extend the provisions of its land rights legislation. New South Wales has made a start by implementing land rights legislation. In Victoria there is preparation for State legislation to achieve land rights for Victorian Aborigines. In the case of the Northern Territory, of course, land rights have been enacted by the Federal Government. But it seems at this stage that the question of Tasmanian land rights will have to be resolved by some sort of Federal Government action, although clearly it is very early days and obviously a great deal of consultation with Aboriginal Tasmanians, the State Government and the Opposition in Tasmania will need to take place before an appropriate course of action can be determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Did recent Press reports of the appointment of a new permanent head of her Department precede that appointment being made by the Governor- General-in-Council, the only place where it could be made? Further, have Press reports today of a full time appointment to the Commonwealth Schools Commission preceded the consideration of that appointment by the Governor-General-in- Council? Alternatively, can the Minister advise the Senate when the Governor- General-in-Council considered the appointments? Can she in fact assure the Senate that the appointment of Mrs Connors to the Commonwealth Schools Commission was approved by the Governor-General-in-Council before it appeared in the Press?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as the honourable senator has noted, that there were some Press reports on the appointment of Dr Wilenski as head of my Department before that appointment had gone through all its proper stages. I was very displeased to note those reports because they did not emanate from the Government or from Government sources. They certainly did not emanate from my office or my Department. But, as the senator who asked the question will be aware, rumours have a habit of getting under way against the best wishes and desires of the Minister in question. It is true that there were some Press reports regarding the appointment of Dr Wilenski before all procedures were gone through.
—Or the Governor-General considered it.

—As I recall, it was the case that those reports appeared. What I must make quite clear is that those reports had no official source whatsoever. They were mere rumours. I can also assure the senator that all proper procedures were followed before any announcement was made. By happy coincidence I was the duty Minister for the signing of Executive Council decisions on the day on which Dr Wilenski's appointment was confirmed, so I am in a position personally to say that all proper procedures were followed. Subsequent to proper procedures being followed an announcement was made and the Government can take no responsibility for any rumours that appeared before.

ANSWER.PARA: I also agree with Senator Peter Baume that there has been at least one report regarding my intentions and the Government's intentions to appoint a new full time commissioner of the Schools Commission. I can only say again that I am most displeased that those reports have appeared. They are rumours; they have no official source. I am certainly displeased as to the content of the report I saw in the Sydney Morning Herald. Taking account of the implication in the senator's question, I cannot make any comment at this stage although, clearly, decisions are in train. When all proper procedures have been gone through and when the Governor-General-in-Council has had an opportunity to approve this appointment I will be happy to make a public statement and, in doing so, correct some misinformation which appeared in today's report in the Sydney Morning Herald.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State and relates to the speech this afternoon by the Governor- General and that section of it that dealt with electoral reform. Is the Attorney -General aware that electors of New South Wales in the recent Senate election had to vote for 62 candidates in order to cast a formal vote and that as a result of this the informal vote was approximately 11 per cent? Will the Government take steps to ensure that this scandalous state of affairs will not occur in the future?
—I am aware of the situation to which the honourable senator referred, and the answer to his question is yes.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that last Saturday, 16 April, the United States television network, National Broadcasting Company, broadcast an excerpt from the so-called Australian documentary, Goodbye Joey? Is it a fact that this film alleges that twice the present annual quota of three million kangaroos are shot each year, that 90 per cent of the roo skins sold are from illegally shot animals and that roo meat is still being sold to the United States market as beef? What information can the Minister give the Senate as to the factual basis of these allegations? In view of the fact that a member of the United States Congress has introduced a Bill to restore the kangaroo to the endangered species list with the effect that the United States market would be closed to the sale of kangaroo products, would the Minister agree that the allegations made on NBC are very damaging to this Australian export industry? What action has the Government taken and what further action will it take to ensure that the American public, members of the United States Congress and the United States Administration are informed of the facts of this industry and the export beef industry as against the fabricated horror scenes and unsubstantiated allegations in Goodbye Joey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government and I share the concern expressed by Senator Martin in her question. I am aware of the reports of the showing on NBC of a particularly exaggerated and melodramatic program and I am also aware of untrue representations of kangaroo harvesting in Australia. Senator Martin listed in her question the allegations contained in those reports. I am advised, with regard to the allegation about cruelty associated with kangaroo harvesting, that kangaroo shooters operate in a generally humane manner and that the film to which Senator Martin's question referred, Goodbye Joey, presents a highly distorted picture. With regard to the action that has been taken to date, I am advised that an Australian wildlife expert was sent to assist embassy staff in presenting a more balanced view of kangaroo harvesting. I should add that, with regard to the cruelty, I share the concern expressed by not only Senator Martin but also other people who have drawn attention to this matter and the Government will montitor the situation very closely.

ANSWER.PARA: Responsibility for kangaroo management rests primarily with State and Territory governments and I believe that these governments are both competent and responsible with regard to this matter. Nevertheless, further ways of improving the situation are being considered. Regarding that part of the honourable senator's question which concerns the attempts to have the red eastern grey and western grey kangaroos listed as endangered species on the United States threatened list, on the basis of evidence the Government has received these species are not endangered and the Australian Government will continue to seek their removal from the United States threatened list. As to further action, the honourable senator may have noted the following statement in the Governor- General's Speech this afternoon:
My Government will improve the measures to protect Australia's fauna and flora, including the introduction of a national kangaroo monitoring group.

I am aware that the thrust of Senator Martin's question was more towards the danger being done to Australian primary industry than to the environmental side but both of these are matters which will be monitored by the national kangaroo monitoring group.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether it is the Government's intention that the Department of Industry and Commerce continue to compile and publish information on new investment in Australia in the periodic report 'Major Manufacturing and Mining Investment Projects', which in the past was used to talk up the resources boom, in view of the deficiences of that series in overstating investment through the inclusion of competing projects where only one could go ahead and the fact that investments recorded could be spread over decades?

—The Government has not made a decision about the future of the survey to which the honourable senator refers. At the moment the matter is subject to review. I see the usefulness of the survey as an information source rather than some of the purposes to which it has been addressed in the past. The schedule is also being reviewed to determine whether it should continue and, if so, in what form and with what modifications. The honourable senator who asked the question referred to some of the deficiencies which have been pointed out in relation to the-
—The question is contrary to Standing Order 99.

—Senator Rae, out of charity, should allow Senator Maguire, on his first day, to address a question in that way. The honourable senator drew attention in his question to some of the deficiencies which have been pointed out in relation to the schedule, and that is certainly true. The Government is concerned that in future it should be used, as I said, for information purposes and not for the sort of purposes it was used for prior to the 1980 election, which was to talk up a resources boom which burst in February the following year . That would not be the purpose of the survey if it continued into the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Attorney-General and is about the Tasmanian spy flights. Has the Attorney-General considered the legality of the orders given by the Minister for Defence to the Royal Australian Air Force to carry out these flights over Tasmania? Can he tell the Senate whether the orders were lawful or otherwise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put on record my resistance to the description of these flights as 'spy flights'. That implies something in the nature of an incursion into a foreign country. I appreciate that on some occasions that is the way in which Tasmanian representatives in this place behave. Indeed, on some occasions it appears as though they come from another planet. I still think that description is nonetheless wildly inappropriate to the occasion and I resist it. As to the legality of the flights in question, I satisfied myself both before the flights took place, and certainly subsequently, that there was no question whatsoever but that the flights were legal. Indeed, in the last three or four days I have had oral confirmation of that perception from the Solicitor-General of Australia with whom I raised that question.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some legal uncertainties about the precise nature and extent of the powers available to the military and the limitations on those powers in the context of aid to the civilian power. There is no question but that under section 61 of the Constitution and with the legislative back-up of the Defence Act under section 51 (6), plus a whole mass of individual pieces of legislation and Defence Force regulations and directions that bear upon this, the flights in question were not only entirely within the range of normal practice so far as the Royal Australian Air Force is concerned but also unquestionably within the legality of the RAAF, and indeed the military role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Attorney 's attention to the fact that, while he has been talking about the legality of the flights, that was not the question. The question I was asking was about the legality of the orders of the Minister for Defence to the RAAF.
—The fact is that the Minister made no such order. The flights were made at the direction of the relevant operational commander in accordance with both military practice and military law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—Senator Crowley opened her batting in this place by asking a question about the allocation of funds under the States Grants (Home Care) Act. The purport of the question and the answer taken together was that there was something to be disturbed about in the manner in which funds were allocated under that Act, in particular in Western Australia and South Australia. As I was the Minister concerned, I would like to advise the Senate that, as was put down by Senator Grimes in his answer, those decisions are made by the Commonwealth following advice from State governments, which advice is based on criteria which have been laid down, such as numbers of aged and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: In all cases that I can recall I acted upon State advice in making approvals or in approving grants under that Act. I have no recollection at all of the particular circumstances in South Australia, apart from receiving representations from all around Australia from individual centres to which my response was that it was a matter which would have to await State government recommendation. I have no recollection of anything other than simply accepting the Department's recommendation. With respect to Western Australia, at the request of the State Minister, the original recommendation to make grants to, I think, three centres, the third of which was the shire of Rockingham, was reconsidered. The State Minister at the time in the previous Government, Mr Young, sought a revision on the basis that another centre in the shire of Melville might be included. I sought further advice from my Department.

There was a change of government. I had some representations from the State Minister. Following those representations, with his approval, people from my office spoke with officers of his State Department who confirmed a State view that the grants should be made to the three centres originally recommended and the centre at Melville. I checked, and my understanding is that the centre at Melville is in a Labor State electorate and in a Labor Federal electorate. I proceeded with the totality of the grants which had been somewhat delayed by the back and forth which had occurred. I wish to reject any suggestion that there was any political motivation in what occurred at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, recognizing the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:

(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention- (a) a delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament take part in the deliberations of the Convention, and comprise sixteen members of the Parliament of whom six shall be members of the Senate and ten shall be members of the House of Representatives;
(b) the six members of the Senate comprise three members of the Australian Labor Party, two members of the Opposition and one member of the Australian Democrats.
(2) That- (a) three Senators being members of the Australian Labor Party, nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two Senators being members of the Opposition, nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one Senator being a member of the Australian Democrats, nominated by the Leader of that Party in the Senate,
(3) That the Prime Minister be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition be the Deputy Leader:
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if- (a) he ceases to be a member of the Commonwealth Parliament;
(b) the House of the Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

(5) That where, because of illness or any other cause, a member of the Delegation is not available to attend a meeting, or part of a meeting, of the Convention, the Leader or senior available member of the Party in the House from which the member was drawn may nominate an alternate member (being a member of the House of which the first-mentioned member is a member) and the member so nominated shall be a member of the Delegation for that meeting, or that part of that meeting:

(6) That, in the event of a member of the Delegation ceasing to be such a member, the Leader of the Party in the House from which the member was drawn may nominate another member (being a member of the House of which the first- mentioned member is or was a member) to replace the first-mentioned member:

(7) That the Leader of the Delegation from time to time make a report for presentation to each House of the Parliament on matters arising out of the Convention, and that the Deputy leader of the Delegation may make an accompanying report.
(8) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of the resolution agreed to by the Senate.

The meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention to be held this year in Adelaide will be the fifth plenary meeting of the Convention. Since the last Convention in Perth in 1978 the standing committees have considered a number of proposals arising from that Convention. On this occasion the Convention will conduct its business in the presence of a number of officially accredited services which will widen the range of participation in the Convention.

The motion I moved is in very similar terms to the motion which was moved prior to the 1978 Convention and earlier motions. It, of course, relates specifically to Commonwealth representation. That will be fixed at 16 delegates, with each State sending 12 delegates and the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory each sending two delegates. There will also be delegates from local government and representatives from each State. There appears to be some concern about the personnel who will attend the Constitutional Convention as representatives of the Commonwealth Parliament. I understand that a document has been circulated in the chamber showing the names of the proposed personnel. The names of the senators representing the Government at the Convention are: Senator Button, Senator Evans and Senator Tate. Mr President, I understand that Senator Chaney, as Leader of the Opposition, will inform you of the names of the Opposition representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion provides for the Opposition to be represented by two senators from the official Opposition and one senator from the Australian Democrats. The two senators from the Liberal-National Party Opposition will be Senator Durack and Senator Rae. We will, pursuant to the motion, appoint some alternate representatives during the Convention but I do not think the Senate is particularly concerned about that. The motion permits that to occur at the Convention.
—Just for the record, Mr President, the Australian Democrats will be represented by me, with Senator Macklin as my alternate.
